docs.lead_paragraph: Peggy Smith peered through the microscope at the two Pap smears and gasped: One merely suggested a case of inflammation. The other clearly showed highly abnormal cells -- cervical cancer. Ms. Smith, a Nashville cytotechnologyist who reads Pap smears for a living, was looking at her own -- and she thinks a new type of Pap smear, called a ThinPrep, saved her life by detecting cancerous cells that a regular Pap the same day did not find.

headline.main: Better Pap Smear Found, but It Is Hardly Used

docs.abstract: US health regulators say ThinPrep Pap smear is significantly more effective than standard Pap smear in detecting abnormal cervical cells, but only a few gyneclogists offer it; ThinPrep, which is manufactured by Cytyc Corp, has been on market for two years; American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology says that there is no proof it saves more lives and that it is too expensive; only a small number of insurers cover it (M)
docs.snippet: Peggy Smith peered through the microscope at the two Pap smears and gasped: One merely suggested a case of inflammation. The other clearly showed highly abnormal cells -- cervical cancer.    Ms. Smith, a Nashville cytotechnologyist who reads Pap...

docs.lead_paragraph: According to a researcher at Harvard University, in any 24-hour period, married women are 50 percent more likely to complain of being in a bad mood than their Y-chromosomed counterparts. The reason, he theorizes, is that married women typically juggle more roles than men do, so they encounter more opportunities for things to go wrong in their lives. Dr. Ronald C. Kessler, a sociologist in the department of health care policy at Harvard Medical School, and a colleague studied 166 couples who kept diaries of their emotions for six weeks.

headline.main: In a Bad Mood - for a Good Reason

docs.abstract: Dr Ronald C Kesler, Harvard sociologist, reports that married women are 50 percent more likely than their married men to complain of being in a bad mood in any 24-hour period; suggests that married women typically juggle more roles than men do, so they encounter more opportunities for things to go wrong in their lives; cartoon (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Finally, a cure for doctors' bad handwriting: the computer. When doctors put down their pens and typed prescriptions into a terminal, serious medication errors dropped by half, researchers at Brigham and Women's Hospital have found. In a study of the drug reactions of almost 7,000 patients before and after a $1.9 million computer system was installed at the Boston hospital, researchers discovered a 55 percent drop in errors after doctors ordered prescriptions on line. The study was published in a recent issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association.
docs.abstract: Serious drug prescription errors drop by 55 percent at Brigham and Women's Hospital after doctors begin ordering drugs on line; system provides a menu selection of medicines and dosages and checks patients' medical histories, drug interactions and allergy problems; also eliminates errors due to bad handwriting (S)
docs.snippet: Finally, a cure for doctors' bad handwriting: the computer. When doctors put down their pens and typed prescriptions into a terminal, serious medication errors dropped by half, researchers at Brigham and Women's Hospital have found.     In a study of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Should parents pay a blood bank to store the blood from their newborn baby's umbilical cord and placenta, in case that child or another family member ever needs it to treat cancer or leukemia? Expectant parents are being urged to do so by companies that have sprung up during the past few years to sell cord-blood banking as a form of ''biological insurance'' against such dreaded diseases. The pitch is based on reports in medical journals, such as a major study published last week in the New England Journal of Medicine, showing that cord blood can sometimes be used in place of a bone marrow transplant.

headline.main: The Hope, and Hype, of Cord Blood

docs.abstract: Expectant parents are urged by a growing private industry to store the blood from their newborn babies' umbilical cords and placentas in case those children or other family members ever need it to treat cancer or leukemia; companies that store and bank cord blood cite research indicating that it can sometimes be used in place of a bone marrow transplant; some experts in bone-marrow transplantion and blood blood banking frown on cord-blood business, arguing that people are being frightened into wasting money on a service they will probably never need; also fear that private banking will limit public access to cord blood; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Should parents pay a blood bank to store the blood from their newborn baby's umbilical cord and placenta, in case that child or another family member ever needs it to treat cancer or leukemia?     Expectant parents are being urged to do so by...

docs.lead_paragraph: When words like ''cure'' and ''prevention'' appear in the title of a book about a chronic, disabling or life-threatening disease, they often enrich authors and publishers at the public's expense. Such is likely the case with a best seller, ''The Breast Cancer Prevention Diet'' by Dr. Bob Arnot, the medical correspondent for NBC. The book's premise -- that adopting a diet rich in soy, flaxseed and fish oils can prevent breast cancer -- has been soundly denounced by breast cancer researchers and patient advocates alike as promising something it cannot possibly deliver.

headline.main: Diet Is Not a Panacea, But It Cuts Risk of Cancer

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody column on diet as a means of reducing the risks of cancer, particularly breast cancer; seconds criticisms that have been leveled against Dr Bob Arnot's best-selling book, The Breast Cancer Prevention Diet, by breast cancer researchers and patient advocates; lists foods that have been shown to help reduce risk of cancer (M)
docs.snippet: When words like ''cure'' and ''prevention'' appear in the title of a book about a chronic, disabling or life-threatening disease, they often enrich authors and publishers at the public's expense. Such is likely the case with a best seller, ''The...

docs.lead_paragraph: After a long delay, the Food and Drug Administration is on the verge of issuing revised guidelines that could enable a new generation of mammography devices to come to the market. The devices rely on digital imaging, a technique experts say offers clearer, more detailed pictures of some breast tissue than traditional X-ray film. Proponents of digital mammography say that it is particularly effective in viewing dense portions of the breast. Dense breast tissue occurs in women of all ages but is more frequent in younger women. ''With a digital image, you can magnify an area and adjust the contrast at a computer workstation so that dense tissue that appears virtually white on film reveals more detail,'' said Dr. Robert Smith, director of cancer screening for the American Cancer Society.
docs.abstract: FDA is expected to revise guidelines on mammography in way that will speed introduction of digital mammography, which improves ability to read dense breast tissue; is accused of moving excessively slow on digital mammography; photos (M)
docs.snippet: After a long delay, the Food and Drug Administration is on the verge of issuing revised guidelines that could enable a new generation of mammography devices to come to the market. The devices rely on digital imaging, a technique experts say offers...

docs.lead_paragraph: For every football player who limps or is carried off the field, there is a soccer player who gloats that soccer is the safer of the two sports. But a study published in the current issue of The British Journal of Sports Medicine reveals that the risk of injury in soccer may have been played down, at least at the professional level. Using videos from 171 domestic and international matches in Britain's professional soccer league, researchers at the Center for Hazard and Risk Management at Loughborough University found that players had a 12 percent risk of injury every game. More significantly, they reported that almost a third of professional players would suffer at least one injury this season.

headline.main: Debunking the Myths of Safety in Soccer

docs.abstract: Study of professional British soccer finds that players have 12 percent risk of injury every game and that almost a third of professional players will suffer at least one injury in a season; only a third of injuries are due to fouls, the rest involving legal contact between opposing players; muscle strains are most common injury, often the result of improper warming up; photo (M)
docs.snippet: For every football player who limps or is carried off the field, there is a soccer player who gloats that soccer is the safer of the two sports. But a study published in the current issue of The British Journal of Sports Medicine reveals that the...

docs.lead_paragraph: When Spinning first reached health clubs a few years ago, it was an instant hit with gym-goers. The International Health Racquet and Sportsclub Association estimates that nearly 46 percent of gyms now offer group cycling classes. The success of Spinning has spawned a new concept in exercise: Group classes are moving out of the aerobics studio and onto the cardiovascular machines found on the gym floor. Treadmill classes in particular are beginning to appear on aerobics schedules all across the country.

headline.main: Taking the Tedium Out of Solitary Workouts

docs.abstract: Popularity of Spinning, the group cycling classes offered at exercise clubs, gives birth of group exercise classes using the treadmill; manufacturers of stair climbers, recumbent cycles and other types of cardiovascular machines are also considering possibility of creating group programming centered around their equipment; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Most people -- linguists included -- ignore 10 percent of all conversation, the ums, likes, false starts and repetitions that litter spontaneous speech. Until recently, these utterances were considered garbage that hindered communication.

headline.main: As Conversation Aid, the 'Oh's' Have It

docs.abstract: Dr Jean E Fox Tree reports that the word 'oh' in the middle of a sentence plays a pivotal role in comprehension, alerting listener to remember a previously mentioned, but then abandoned, idea; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Most people -- linguists included -- ignore 10 percent of all conversation, the ums, likes, false starts and repetitions that litter spontaneous speech.    Until recently, these utterances were considered garbage that hindered communication.

docs.lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, my mother's mind went to battle with Alzheimer's disease and lost. Last month scientists at New York University Medical Center, in a hunt for clues to the blight of her brain, spent three days looking at mine. It is because I survived the enormous effect of this illness in my family that I was willing to undergo this investigation. Family members of patients think of ourselves as survivors: We saw the disease rage through our lives and turn children into parents, kill spouses from exhaustion and financially devastate us along the way.

headline.main: In an N.Y.U. Lab, Premonitions of Alzheimer's

docs.abstract: Marion Roach article on her participation in New York University study of brains of children of Alzheimer's victims, in hopes of discovering changes that lead some people to develop disease; Dr Mony de Leon explains research showing how hippocampus shrinks as disease progresses; photos showing size of hippocampus in young adult, in Roach at age 42, in television journalist Hugh Downs at 76 and in Alzheimer's patient; Downs is example of normal older subject, who has normal memory even though hippocampus shows age-related size reduction; de Leon notes lack of knowledge about pre-Alzheimer's (M)
